Subject: Re: [neat] Batching the population on GPU?

------=_Part_13322539_859321015.1493349731381
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Thanks, Colin for your response.
There is definitely something to be said f=
or leveraging hardware-supported vector matrix processing. But perhaps one =
might want to use the results of NEAT in places where such hardware support=
 might not be present, for instance, embedded systems and the like.
Also, c=
orrect me if I'm wrong, but most are not going to be doing vector math on e=
ach individual neuron's inputs, but treat the entire neural network as a sp=
arse matrix.=C2=A0
I have not had much time to look at the current state of=
 affairs with GPUs and the like, and sparse matrix algorithms -- and even t=
he efficient representation of sparse matrices in RAM suitable for the hard=
ware matrix support. So I have some homework to do for sure. Also, that's n=
ot to say I can't also leverage the same in RubyNEAT, for my design will al=
low that kind of representation without too much fuss, and I'm considering =
more direct matrix support anyway.
Back during the times of Koza, I had got=
ten interested in Genetic Programming. It seems to not have gained any trac=
tion at all over the years. My current implementation as functional program=
ming basically IS Genetic Programming in a structured manner.
Eventually I =
want to leverage LLVM to represent the neural networks using my approach, a=
nd I do wonder if doing the vector math "on the stack" as compiled code wou=
ld not approach the speed of the sparse matrix approach, at least in some s=
ituations. And that's not to say the LLVM can't also leverage hardware-assi=
sted matrix operations as well.

Kind Regards,

Fred Mitchell,=C2=A0


=C2=
=A0Skype: flajann
 

    On Saturday, 22 April 2017, 12:36, "Colin Green co=
lin.green1@... [neat]" <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
 

 =C2=A0   On =
22 April 2017 at 11:09, Fred Mitchell lordalveric@... [neat]
<neat@ya=
hoogroups.com> wrote:
>
>
> Has anyone else taken this functional approach?=
 Or are most implementations
> relying on matrices? Any thoughts as to whic=
h approach is better?
>

Hi Fred,

The first thing to note is that the prop=
agation of an array of input
signals through a layer of weights, and summin=
g to produce an output
array - this is conceptually vector-matrix multiplic=
ation. How we
choose to do this is an implementation detail, but conceptual=
ly we're
all doing vector-matrix multiplication.

In terms of performance, =
the fastest approach is always going to be to
use hardware acceleration tha=
t is designed to do matrix
multiplication. (Or rather, this is always going=
 to be the most
efficient approach, since you could make things very fast b=
y
distributing work out to a great many servers doing slow matrix
multiplic=
ation in software instead of hardware.) This is why most AI
type workloads =
have migrated to GPUs, and why google created the TPU -
at their heart thes=
e hardware platforms are providing faster and more
efficient means of perfo=
rming matrix multiplication.

The hardware matrix multiplication support fu=
ndamentally relies on the
data being operated on being in contiguous chucks=
 of memory, since
this allows all of the data to be operated on to be loade=
d
efficiently, e.g in CPUs this gives good utilisation of the CPU
caches, w=
hereas out of order RAM accesses will cause many cache
misses, and access t=
o RAM is orders or magnitude slower than the
various CPU caches (the L1 to =
L3 or even level 4 caches).

I'm don't think this necessarily conflicts wit=
h the functional
programming approach, but as with non-functional (procedur=
al)
programming models it probably does influence how you arrange data
stru=
ctures in memory and how you structure the algorithms to operate
on those d=
ata structures. Fortunately, matrix multiplication is such a
fundamental op=
eration there is much support out there that can be
leveraged. And we we no=
w have at least three large corporations
throwing lots of money primarily a=
t making matrix multiplication
faster (Nvidia, google, Intel), so things mi=
ght get even more
interesting in the coming years.

Colin

    <div id=3D"yiv8197998900ygrp-text">
      =

      
      <div>On 22 April 2017 at 11:09, Fred Mitchell lordalveric@yah=
oo.com [neat]<br clear=3D"none">
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:<br cle=
ar=3D"none">
><br clear=3D"none">
><br clear=3D"none">
> Has anyon=
e else taken this functional approach? Or are most implementations<br clear=
=3D"none">
> relying on matrices? Any thoughts as to which approach is b=
etter?<br clear=3D"none">
><br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
Hi Fr=
ed,<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
The first thing to note is that =
the propagation of an array of input<br clear=3D"none">
signals through a l=
ayer of weights, and summing to produce an output<br clear=3D"none">
array =
- this is conceptually vector-matrix multiplication. How we<br clear=3D"non=
e">
choose to do this is an implementation detail, but conceptually we're<b=
r clear=3D"none">
all doing vector-matrix multiplication.<br clear=3D"none"=
>
<br clear=3D"none">
In terms of performance, the fastest approach is alwa=
ys going to be to<br clear=3D"none">
use hardware acceleration that is desi=
gned to do matrix<br clear=3D"none">
multiplication. (Or rather, this is al=
ways going to be the most<br clear=3D"none">
efficient approach, since you =
could make things very fast by<br clear=3D"none">
distributing work out to =
a great many servers doing slow matrix<br clear=3D"none">
multiplication in=
 software instead of hardware.) This is why most AI<br clear=3D"none">
type=
 workloads have migrated to GPUs, and why google created the TPU -<br clear=
=3D"none">
at their heart these hardware platforms are providing faster and=
 more<br clear=3D"none">
efficient means of performing matrix multiplicatio=
n.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
The hardware matrix multiplicatio=
n support fundamentally relies on the<br clear=3D"none">
data being operate=
d on being in contiguous chucks of memory, since<br clear=3D"none">
this al=
lows all of the data to be operated on to be loaded<br clear=3D"none">
effi=
ciently, e.g in CPUs this gives good utilisation of the CPU<br clear=3D"non=
e">
caches, whereas out of order RAM accesses will cause many cache<br clea=
r=3D"none">
misses, and access to RAM is orders or magnitude slower than th=
e<br clear=3D"none">
various CPU caches (the L1 to L3 or even level 4 cache=
s).<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
I'm don't think this necessarily=
 conflicts with the functional<br clear=3D"none">
programming approach, but=
 as with non-functional (procedural)<br clear=3D"none">
programming models =
it probably does influence how you arrange data<br clear=3D"none">
structur=
es in memory and how you structure the algorithms to operate<br clear=3D"no=
ne">
on those data structures. Fortunately, matrix multiplication is such a=
<br clear=3D"none">
fundamental operation there is much support out there t=
hat can be<br clear=3D"none">
leveraged. And we we now have at least three =
large corporations<br clear=3D"none">
throwing lots of money primarily at m=
aking matrix multiplication<br clear=3D"none">
faster (Nvidia, google, Inte=
l), so things might get even more<br clear=3D"none">
interesting in the com=
ing years.<br clear=3D"none">
<br clear=3D"none">
Colin<br clear=3D"none">
=
</div>

    </div>
